bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Florence M. Read, November 9, 1923

div1.p: Noguchi discusses possible yellow fever cases and sends reports.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Florence M. Read, November 9, 1923
div1.opener:
Carter
COPY
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
for MEDICAL RESEARCH
66 Street and Avenue A
New York
November 9, 1923
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
On October 23 Dr. Russell sent me tissues of 2 cases
of suspected yellow fever forwarded by Dr. Miller from Colombia,
the names of the patients being José Antonio Viviesca and
David Manrique. He requested that I send a report on the
tissues which he might forward to Dr. Miller.

To judge from the histological findings, both cases
might very well be yellow fever, the changes being such as very
often occur in cases of undoubted yellow fever. The clinical
history in the case of Viviesca is also strikingly like yellow
fever.

From the clinical history of the patient Manrique we
cannot exclude the possibility of his disease having been a very
severe acute type of infectious jaundice.

I am enclosing herewith Dr. Muller's detailed report on
the tissues. We have sent a set of slides to Dr. Darling, as Dr.
Russell requested.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) Hideyo Noguchi
P.S. In such instances as these, we should always be glad to
have a copy of Dr. Darling's report when you receive it.
Miss Florence M. Read
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
